item.title: Internet SDN Mimics MPLS At Much Lower Cost
item.description: By: John Shepler Traditionally, businesses have faced a trade-off between expensive, high-performance WAN bandwidth and affordable, but unreliable, low-performance options. While cable or DSL internet offers cost savings, their inconsistent performance can be problematic. Conversely, dedicated private lines or MPLS networks deliver reliability and performance at a premium cost. If only there were a solution to make the internet perform like an MPLS network at a fraction of the cost. Thanks to SDN, there is.

item.title: Business Phone Line Options
item.description: By: John Shepler Every business, regardless of size, requires at least one telephone line. While phone lines may seem straightforward, you might have more choices than you realize. Are you confident that your business has the most suitable phone line? Plain Old Telephone Service The traditional analog phone line, known as POTS (Plain Old Telephone Service), is a basic and familiar option. POTS lines are simple, consisting of a single twisted copper pair connecting a standard RJ-11 phone jack on your wall directly to the telephone company’s central office.

item.title: Cloud Computing and WAN Bandwidth
item.description: The increasing popularity of cloud computing in IT services has led to a rush towards all things cloud-related. However, the crucial role of WAN bandwidth in accessing the cloud often gets overlooked. WAN, or Wide Area Network, typically refers to any connection outside of an office or corporate campus. While connections within a city might utilize a MAN (Metropolitan Area Network) limited to a smaller area, reaching distant locations or networks necessitates WAN bandwidth.

item.title: IP WAN over MPLS Advantages
item.description: The internet is often the first thing that comes to mind when considering IP wide area networks. Although it boasts near-universal accessibility and relatively low access costs, it presents significant drawbacks for business use. Factors like bandwidth, latency, jitter, and packet loss lack guarantees and predictability. Additionally, security on the internet is unreliable. However, are alternative methods for interconnecting business locations excessively expensive or difficult to manage? It’s feasible to establish a private IP network that enables the use of your existing IP addressing system, eliminating the need for encryption, firewalls, tunnels, or supplementary hardware.

item.title: When More Bandwidth Doesnâ€™t Help
item.description: You’re likely aware of this situation: your reliable internet connection, a T1 line or DS3 circuit, has suddenly become sluggish. Your VoIP calls sound distant, employees struggle to work, and frustrated customers can’t even communicate properly. The obvious solution seems to be getting more bandwidth, right? While that seems logical, doubling your internet speed might not solve the problem, leaving you with the same issues and double the cost. Why is that?

item.title: Ethernet VPLS Extends Your LAN Network
item.description: Traditional methods of connecting multiple business locations, such as Frame Relay, VSAT satellite terminals, internet-based VPNs, and dedicated T1 lines, have been around for a while. However, a new technology called Ethernet VPLS offers superior performance and cost advantages, making it a compelling option for businesses with multiple locations, including branch offices, retail franchises, and medical clinics. Ethernet VPLS, which stands for Virtual Private LAN service, essentially functions as a carrier-managed local area network that can span across cities, states, or even the entire country.

item.title: What Dynamic CoS Means to You
item.description: By: John Shepler Modern networks are typically converged, meaning they handle various traffic types like backups, file transfers, cloud access, VoIP calls, streaming, and web services. This begs the question: how can we ensure these networks maintain the integrity of each process with so much going on? The Need for QoS When we implement Quality of Service (QoS) controls, a network becomes more than just a passive conduit. But why is this necessary?

item.title: VXSuite Takes the Scary Out of VoIP
item.description: By: John Shepler You understand that Unified Communications, powered by VoIP telephony, is the future of business communication. You also recognize its potential to boost productivity. However, the fear of completely overhauling your existing system is holding you back. While your current phones, connected through old wiring, might seem adequate for making and receiving calls, they limit your communication capabilities. To unlock more advanced features, transitioning to an all-IP network is essential.

item.title: Transforming the WAN Into The Smart WAN
item.description: People tend to think of WAN connections as basic channels for data, similar to how Senator Ted Stevens once described the internet. However, with the shift from on-site data centers to cloud-based systems, VoIP, and video streaming, our needs have outgrown this simple model. This is where the concept of a Smart WAN comes into play. Instead of treating all data equally, a Smart WAN prioritizes different types of data through a system called Class of Service (CoS).

item.title: Your Own Private Information Superhighway
item.description: The internet is often compared to a superhighway, and for good reason: it can take you almost anywhere, just like a road system. However, just like real highways, the internet has its drawbacks, such as traffic jams that slow everything down. These slowdowns are especially common in high-traffic areas or on connections with limited capacity. One significant difference between the internet and physical highways is the lack of traffic prioritization. Unlike ambulances that get preferential treatment on roads, all internet traffic is treated equally.

item.title: Build Your Own World Wide Web
item.description: By: John Shepler The internet has its downsides despite the benefits of global and instant information access. Sharing large files between offices, conducting high-quality teleconferences, and experiencing seamless application interactions can be challenging. Network crashes, congestion from high-bandwidth activities, and constant security threats further diminish the internet’s appeal. So, is there a better alternative? The Connectivity Conundrum Imagine having an exclusive internet solely for your business, customers, and suppliers. Bandwidth wouldn’t be an issue, and the network would operate seamlessly.

item.title: Why International MPLS Connections Make Sense
item.description: Businesses with multiple branches, even those with only two, are realizing the benefits of MPLS network services for domestic and global connections. Let’s explore what MPLS offers, particularly for international connections, and why it’s a practical solution even for single-link setups. Multi-Protocol Label Switching (MPLS) is a network technology designed to carry data for numerous users while maintaining security, service quality, and crucial network attributes such as bandwidth, latency, jitter, and packet loss.

item.title: Why Cloud Data Centers Are Multiplying
item.description: The number of cloud-based service offerings has significantly increased, with almost every telecom and IT company seemingly having a cloud offering. But what’s causing this rapid growth? There are two primary factors driving the implementation of cloud computing services. First, a robust data center is needed to house all the necessary equipment, along with adequate cooling, backup power, and security. Second, reliable connectivity is crucial. A groundbreaking cloud service is useless if it can’t be delivered reliably.

item.title: Should You Buy VoIP as a Service?
item.description: Cloud-based services, including Voice over Internet Protocol (VoIP), have been around for a while. What’s becoming more popular now is the trend of large businesses connecting their different locations using SIP Trunks and all sizes of businesses choosing to outsource their PBX functionality. This can be considered VoIP as a Service. Many home and small business users adopted cloud-based VoIP early on to cut costs. They did this by replacing their traditional phone lines and using their broadband internet connection for both high-speed internet and phone service.

item.title: 5 Ways to Access An MPLS Network
item.description: MPLS networks have become a sought-after alternative to costly, proprietary WAN networks and the public internet, which can present performance and security challenges. Let’s explore what MPLS networks offer and the various ways to access them. Imagine an MPLS network as a dedicated internet exclusively for businesses. Privately owned and operated, MPLS networks don’t provide services or connections for residential users, making them strictly business-to-business (B2B). Numerous service providers operate their own MPLS networks, offering regional, national, or international coverage.

item.title: SIP Trunks vs EoC vs T1
item.description: Not long ago, businesses seeking a dedicated, symmetrical bandwidth line had only one option: T1. However, the landscape has changed with the emergence of Ethernet over Copper (EoC) and SIP Trunks. While options like DSL, Cable, satellite, and 3G wireless offer shared and asymmetrical bandwidth, and DS3, SONET, and Ethernet over Fiber provide higher bandwidths at higher costs, they fall outside the scope of this comparison. Similar to their copper-based counterparts, Ethernet over Fiber, DS3, and SONET are higher bandwidth alternatives to EoC, T1, and SIP Trunks, respectively.

item.title: A New Edge On Private IP Networks
item.description: With the increase in businesses operating from multiple locations, IP network solutions have become more affordable and accessible. New Edge Networks, a key player in this domain, specializes in private IP-based WANs, offering enhanced quality and performance for connecting multiple business sites by bypassing the public internet. While the internet has revolutionized global communication, its ubiquity and open nature pose limitations for businesses. Network neutrality principles treat all data equally, regardless of its importance.
